Generate and Instantiate What You Prefer: Text-Guided Diffusion for Sequential Recommendation

Guoqing Hu University of Science and Technology of China HugoChinn@mail.ustc.edu.cn ,  Zhengyi Yang University of Science and Technology of China yangzhy@mail.ustc.edu.cn ,  Zhibo Cai Renmin University of China caizhibo@ruc.edu.cn ,  An Zhang National University of Singapore an˙zhang@nus.edu.sg  and  Xiang Wang University of Science and Technology of China xiangwang1223@gmail.com
(2025)
Abstract.

Recent advancements in generative recommendation systems, particularly in the realm of sequential recommendation tasks, have shown promise in enhancing generalization to new items. Among these approaches, diffusion-based generative recommendation has emerged as an effective tool, leveraging its ability to capture data distributions and generate high-quality samples. Despite effectiveness, two primary challenges have been identified: 1) the lack of consistent modeling of data distribution for oracle items; and 2) the difficulty in scaling to more informative control signals beyond historical interactions. These issues stem from the uninformative nature of ID embeddings, which necessitate random initialization and limit the incorporation of additional control signals. To address these limitations, we propose iDreamRec to involve more concrete prior knowledge to establish item embeddings, particularly through detailed item text descriptions and advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM). More importantly, by converting item descriptions into embeddings aligned with TEM, we enable the integration of intention instructions as control signals to guide the generation of oracle items. Experimental results on four datasets demonstrate that iDreamRec not only outperforms existing diffusion-based generative recommenders but also facilitates the incorporation of intention instructions for more precise and effective recommendation generation.

Text Embeddings, Diffusion Models, Sequential Recommendation

1. Introduction

Recent advances in generative recommendation, especially in sequential recommendation scenarios (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Tang and Wang, 2018; Hidasi et al., 2016), have shown promising results due to the ability to generalize better to new items (Rajput et al., 2023; Yang et al., 2023; Wang et al., 2023a, b; Yu et al., 2023). Among various generative frameworks, diffusion models (Ho et al., 2020; Nichol and Dhariwal, 2021; Song et al., 2021a; Song and Ermon, 2019, 2020; Song et al., 2021b, 2023) have emerged as highly effective, largely due to their theoretical strengths in modeling complex data distributions and generating high-quality samples. For example, DreamRec (Yang et al., 2023) employs a diffusion model, conditioned on the interaction histories of users, to predict the distribution of subsequent items (i.e., oracle items) and ground them to the real items users are likely to interact with. The learning objective in this framework is to generate oracle item embeddings through conditional diffusion processes, where the embeddings are simultaneously optimized alongside the model parameters.

Despite the effectiveness of DreamRec, we identify two inherent limitations that constrain its potential to fully exploit diffusion models in generative recommendation:

  • •

    Inconsistent Data Distribution of Oracle Items. While diffusion models, in general, are excel in capturing consistent data distributions according to their theoretical underpinnings (Ho et al., 2020; Song and Ermon, 2019; Song et al., 2021b), DreamRec diverges from this principle. Instead of relying on pre-existing fixed item representations, DreamRec randomly initializes item embeddings which are then jointly optimized with model parameters during training. This process lacks a stable anchor in the latent space, causing item embeddings to fluctuate and evolve over time. Consequently, this instability leads to inconsistent data distribution for oracle items, ultimately degrading the performance of generative recommendation.

  • •

    Limited Exploration to More Informative Controls. Although DreamRec effectively uses interaction histories as control signals to generate oracle items, it struggles to incorporate richer control signals, such as user intentions. For example, a user might express an intent like “I want to read a book about a young boy who discovers his magical heritage, attends a hidden school of wizardry, and confronts a dark evil” (the example of intention in Figure 1(c)), which could lead to a recommendation like Harry Potter. However, as illustrated in Figure 1(b), the reliance on interaction histories limits the model’s ability to generate more nuanced and relevant recommendations, thereby constraining the full generative potential of diffusion models.

We attribute these limitations to a core issue: the reliance on learning item embeddings based solely on IDs. This not only requires random initialization, but also makes it challenging to incorporate additional control signals. A promising solution is to enrich item embeddings with more substantial prior knowledge beyond mere ID information. Furthermore, if the prior knowledge is interpretable by humans, it could enable the integration of intention instructions alongside interaction histories to better guide the generation process. Inspired by the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) (Brown et al., 2020; Touvron et al., 2023), leveraging the extensive world knowledge embedded within LLMs presents a valuable opportunity. However, how to effectively apply LLMs to create informative prior knowledge for item embeddings remains largely unexplored in diffusion-based generative recommendation. In this paper, we propose iDreamRec (intention-guided DreamRec), incorporating text embeddings from LLMs to accurately model item distributions and generate oracle items. Specifically, given the metadata about items (e.g., titles), we first prompt GPT (Brown et al., 2020) to generate detailed textual descriptions, offering richer content than simple item IDs. To transform such descriptions into item embeddings, we employ the advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM) (Li et al., 2023c; Liu et al., 2019; Gao et al., 2021; Muennighoff, 2022) provided by OpenAI 111https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/embeddings. This approach allows for converting variable-length descriptions into consistent, context-aware item embeddings. On this consistent embedding space, we train a diffusion model conditioned on interaction histories using a classifier-free guidance strategy (Ho and Salimans, 2022) as Algorithm 1. Crucially, as item embeddings align with TEM, intention instructions can also be translated into embeddings within the same space, providing refined control signals for generating oracle items (as shown in Figure 1(c)). Intent instructions can also be integrated with interaction histories to generate more nuanced and relevant oracle items (as illustrated in Figure 1(d)). For concrete examples, please refer to Figure 3.

Evaluations on four benchmark datasets suggest that iDreamRec not only outperforms current diffusion-based recommenders (e.g., DreamRec (Yang et al., 2023), DiffRec (Wang et al., 2023b)), but also enables the integration of intention instructions to guide the generation of oracle items.

2. Related Work

Diffusion models have shown extraordinary performance in various generative tasks, including image synthesis (Dhariwal and Nichol, 2021; Peebles and Xie, 2023), text generation (Li et al., 2022; Gong et al., 2023), 3D molecular modeling (Song et al., 2024), biological sequence design (Avdeyev et al., 2023) and anomaly detection (Livernoche et al., 2024). The effectiveness of diffusion models stems from their training stability and high sampling quality in capturing the data distribution given observed samples compared to GANs (Goodfellow et al., 2014; Arjovsky et al., 2017) and VAEs (Kingma and Welling, 2014; Maaløe et al., 2019). In general, diffusion models can be derived through the following three approaches: denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho et al., 2020; Song et al., 2021a), score-based generative models (SGM) (Song and Ermon, 2019, 2020), and stochastic differential equations (SDE) (Song et al., 2021b), which has theoretically shown to be equivalent and achieve similar performance in practice (Song et al., 2021b; Luo, 2022). Specifically, SGM is a discrete form of variance-exploding SDE, while DDPM is a discrete form of variance-preserving SDE. In terms of application, works tend to adopt the DDPM framework (e.g., StableDiffusion (Rombach et al., 2022), DiT (Peebles and Xie, 2023)) due to its flexibility in adapting to different scenarios.

Diffusion-based recommenders can be roughly classified into generative and discriminative ones according to their task formulation. Specifically, diffusion-based discriminative recommenders either predict interaction probability vectors for all items per user (Wang et al., 2023b; Bénédict et al., 2023) or treat the diffusion model as a powerful enhancement for traditional discriminative recommenders, which is jointly trained under classification or ranking losses such as cross-entropy of Bayesian Personalized Ranking (Qin et al., 2024; Li et al., 2023b; Wang et al., 2024; Du et al., 2023). To fully leverage the powerful generative capability of the diffusion model, the diffusion-based generative recommender (i.e., DreamRec) reshapes sequential recommendation as generation of the subsequent item embedding (aka. oracle item embedding) under the condition of the interaction history (Yang et al., 2023). However, DreamRec adopts randomly initialized and trainable ID embeddings similar to traditional sequential recommenders (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Tang and Wang, 2018; Hidasi et al., 2016), which might bring practical challenges (as discussed in Section 1).

Text embedding model (TEM) aims to encode massive text into a unified semantic space with context awareness. Most TEMs are fine-tuned on large language models (LLM, e.g., BERT (Devlin et al., 2019), T5 (Raffel et al., 2020), GPT (Brown et al., 2020)) with the contrastive learning objective. In the previous, BERT-based TEMs are widely used to acquire text embeddings for downstream tasks (Li et al., 2023c; Liu et al., 2019; Beltagy et al., 2020; Gao et al., 2021). Recently, as GPT (Brown et al., 2020) has shown prevailing capability in natural language tasks, it becomes more promising to employ GPT-based TEMs, which are available via OpenAI Embedding API (Neelakantan et al., 2022).

Large language models for recommendation (LLM4Recs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities. In general, LLM4Recs can be divided into LLM-based recommenders and LLM-enhanced recommenders. LLM-based recommenders consider LLM as the backbone of recommenders (Bao et al., 2023b, a; Li et al., 2023a; Liao et al., 2024; Zhai et al., 2024), while LLM-enhanced recommenders view LLM as a powerful feature extractor (Ren et al., 2024; Wei et al., 2024; Sheng et al., 2024). Despite their powerful performance, LLM-based recommenders still face challenges such as high fine-tuning costs and relatively low recommendation efficiency. In practice, LLM-enhanced recommenders are more lightweight and feasible.

3. Preliminary

In this section, we introduce the diffusion-based generative recommendation, basically following DreamRec (Yang et al., 2023). Here, denoising diffusion implicit models (DDIM) (Song et al., 2021a) form the core of the diffusion framework. In contrast to the denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho et al., 2020) originally employed in DreamRec, DDIM provides faster sampling and enhances sampling quality. See Appendix A for more details on DDIM and Table 2 for the symbol definitions.

4. Method

In this section, we introduce our proposed iDreamRec, aiming to build a more consistent item distribution for the diffusion-based generative recommendation, as well as involving intention instructions into the conditional guidance to generate more targeted and relevant oracle items.

4.1. Consistent Item Embedding Modeling

We identify that the core limitation of previous diffusion-based generative recommenders stems from uninformative ID embeddings, which might impair the generalization ability of diffusion models due to inconsistency during training (Daras et al., 2023, 2024). To resolve this issue, we propose incorporating prior knowledge encoded in LLMs to create a more consistent embedding distribution of items for diffusion-based generative recommendation.

4.1.1. Prompting ChatGPT to Enrich Item Description

To create a more consistent embedding distribution of items than learnable ID embeddings, it is crucial to include richer prior knowledge about items. However, in real-world scenarios, the available information about items is often limited. To overcome this, we propose using ChatGPT (Brown et al., 2020) to acquire more detailed and coherent descriptions of items, leveraging its extensive world knowledge. Specifically, given basic information of items 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v (e.g., titles), we design prompts to extract more comprehensive descriptions from ChatGPT. Here is an example in the movie recommendation scenario:

By prompting ChatGPT, we can generate detailed descriptions for item v𝑣vitalic_v, denoted as 𝒯vsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

4.1.2. Embedding item description via Text Embedding Model

After enriching the item description (i.e., 𝒯vsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) by prompting GPT, the next step is to construct a consistent item embedding distribution that effectively captures the information within 𝒯vsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A straightforward approach is to leverage open-sourced Language Models (e.g., BERT (Devlin et al., 2019), LLaMA (Touvron et al., 2023)) to generate token-level embeddings of 𝒯vsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, this presents practical challenges, as the length of descriptions varies significantly across items, which conflicts with the diffusion models’ requirement for embeddings to have identical dimensions. While simple aggregation or pooling methods can generate embeddings with consistent dimensions, they may fail to adequately generalize or retain the necessary information.

Inspired by recent advances in Text Embedding Models (TEMs) (Li et al., 2023c; Liu et al., 2019; Beltagy et al., 2020; Gao et al., 2021; Ni et al., 2022a, b; Neelakantan et al., 2022), which are pre-trained to convert sentences into fixed-dimension embeddings while preserving semantics, we propose leveraging TEMs to generate embeddings for item descriptions. Specifically, for an item v𝑣vitalic_v with a detailed description 𝒯vsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathcal{T}_{v}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we employ a TEM to obtain its corresponding embedding:

(7) 𝐞v=TEM-Enc⁢(𝒯v),subscript𝐞𝑣TEM-Encsubscript𝒯𝑣\mathbf{e}_{v}=\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\mathcal{T}_{v}),bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = TEM-Enc ( caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where TEM-Enc⁢(⋅)TEM-Enc⋅\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\cdot)TEM-Enc ( ⋅ ) denotes the encoder of TEM, and 𝐞vsubscript𝐞𝑣\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the resulting text embedding. Since 𝐞vsubscript𝐞𝑣\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT encapsulates rich, relevant information from GPT and TEM, it remains frozen throughout training. Then, we obtain the text embedding matrix 𝐄∈ℝ|ℐ|×d𝐄superscriptℝℐ𝑑\mathbf{E}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{I}|\times d}bold_E ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_I | × italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of all items in ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I, where d𝑑ditalic_d is the embedding dimension. Consequently, diffusion models can focus on capturing a more consistent distribution of items based on GPT-enhanced text embeddings from TEM, rather than relying on uninformative, trainable ID embeddings.

4.1.3. Linear Transformation for Text Embeddings

Inspired by the whitening transformation for text semantic similarity (Su et al., 2021) (i.e., an orthogonal transformation with scaling for text embeddings), we propose a linear transformation 𝒜⁢(⋅):𝒜⁢(𝐞)=(𝐞−𝐚)⁢𝐀:𝒜⋅𝒜𝐞𝐞𝐚𝐀\mathcal{A}(\cdot):\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\mathbf{a})\mathbf{A}caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) : caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_a ) bold_A for text embedding matrix 𝐄𝐄\mathbf{E}bold_E where 𝐚∈ℝd𝐚superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{a}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_a ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}italic_A ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d × italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT both are heuristically defined. For example, this transformation can either be a simple scaling constant a∈ℝ𝑎ℝa\in\mathbb{R}italic_a ∈ blackboard_R or an orthogonal transformation with scaling, known as a normal transformation. Specifically, 𝒜⁢(⋅):𝒜⁢(𝐞)=a⁢𝐞:𝒜⋅𝒜𝐞𝑎𝐞\mathcal{A}(\cdot):\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=a\mathbf{e}caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) : caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = italic_a bold_e or 𝒜⁢(⋅):𝒜⁢(𝐞)=(𝐞−𝐚)⁢𝐎𝐃:𝒜⋅𝒜𝐞𝐞𝐚𝐎𝐃\mathcal{A}(\cdot):\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\mathbf{a})\mathbf{O}% \mathbf{D}caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) : caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_a ) bold_OD where 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}bold_D is a diagonal matrix and 𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O}bold_O is an orthogonal matrix.

To pre-define a normal transformation for text embedding matrix 𝐄𝐄\mathbf{E}bold_E, we can first calculate its variance matrix Var⁢(𝐄)Var𝐄\text{Var}(\mathbf{E})Var ( bold_E ) and then conduct orthogonal matrix decomposition (Lang, 2004; Axler, 1996; F.R.S., 1901):

(8) Var⁢(𝐄)=𝐎⁢Λ⁢𝐎T,Var𝐄𝐎Λsuperscript𝐎𝑇\text{Var}(\mathbf{E})=\mathbf{O}\Lambda\mathbf{O}^{T},Var ( bold_E ) = bold_O roman_Λ bold_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where matrix 𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O}bold_O is orthogonal and ΛΛ\Lambdaroman_Λ is diagonal. Therefore, various normal transformations can be constructed, such as 𝒜⁢(𝐞)=𝐞𝐎⁢Λ−12𝒜𝐞𝐞𝐎superscriptΛ12\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=\mathbf{e}\mathbf{O}\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = bold_eO roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝒜⁢(𝐞)=𝐞𝐎⁢Λ−12⁢𝐎𝒜𝐞𝐞𝐎superscriptΛ12𝐎\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=\mathbf{e}\mathbf{O}\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}\mathbf{O}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = bold_eO roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O, and 𝒜⁢(𝐞)=𝐞𝐎⁢Λ−12⁢𝐎T𝒜𝐞𝐞𝐎superscriptΛ12superscript𝐎𝑇\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=\mathbf{e}\mathbf{O}\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}\mathbf{O}^{T}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = bold_eO roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here, Λ−12superscriptΛ12\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the reciprocal square root of the diagonal elements of ΛΛ\Lambdaroman_Λ.

Inheriting from whitening transformation, our linear transformation 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) can enhance the effectiveness of semantic matching for text embeddings (Su et al., 2021). Beyond that, the transformed text embedding matrix 𝒜⁢(𝐄)𝒜𝐄\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{E})caligraphic_A ( bold_E ) is inherently better suited for DDIM-based generative recommenders. On the one hand, Var⁢(𝒜⁢(𝐄))Var𝒜𝐄\text{Var}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{E}))Var ( caligraphic_A ( bold_E ) ) can better perverse variance in the DDIM framework. As a result, the row vectors of 𝒜⁢(𝐄)𝒜𝐄\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{E})caligraphic_A ( bold_E ) will be maximally separated from each other, collectively filling the space of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as fully as possible (Lang, 2004; Axler, 1996; F.R.S., 1901). This makes it easier for the generated oracle item embeddings to find the most relevant items.

4.2. Intention Guidance via Text Embedding Models

As discussed in Section 1, another key limitation of current diffusion-based generative recommenders is the difficulty in incorporating more informative control signals, such as intention instructions, to guide the generation of oracle items. This is largely due to the fact that the randomly initialized item embeddings are hardly interpretable by humans (Daras et al., 2023, 2024). In contrast, we have introduced TEM to acquire item embedding from textual descriptions of items, making them easier to understand in natural language. This allows us to incorporate intention instructions, which reflect user intentions or prior knowledge, into the control signal.

Specifically, consider an intention instruction denoted as 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y in natural language. Here is an example of intention instruction in the movie recommendation scenario:

By employing TEM-Enc⁢(⋅)TEM-Enc⋅\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\cdot)TEM-Enc ( ⋅ ), the encoder of TEM on the top of 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, we can obtain the embedding of intention instruction 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y:

(12) 𝐞𝒴=TEM-Enc⁢(𝒴),subscript𝐞𝒴TEM-Enc𝒴\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}=\textbf{TEM-Enc}(\mathcal{Y}),bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = TEM-Enc ( caligraphic_Y ) ,

where 𝐞𝒴subscript𝐞𝒴\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the embedding of intention instruction, which lies in the same semantic space as the text embedding matrix of items 𝐄𝐄\mathbf{E}bold_E due to the employ of the same TEM encoder.

To generate oracle items align with these intention instructions, we can simply modify the generation process in iDreamRec by fusing 𝐞𝒴subscript𝐞𝒴\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the condition signal 𝐞<Lsubscript𝐞absent𝐿\mathbf{e}_{<L}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from interaction histories:

In our experiments, we use a Diffusion Transformer (DiT) Block with in-context conditioning (Peebles and Xie, 2023).

Note that we do not explicitly involve intention instructions during the training process. Since the embedding of intention instruction 𝐞𝒴subscript𝐞𝒴\mathbf{e}_{\mathcal{Y}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the item embedding 𝐞vsubscript𝐞𝑣\mathbf{e}_{v}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are distributed in the same semantic space as the output space of TEM encoder, the intention instruction can be seamlessly integrated into the generation phase of iDreamRec as Algorithm 2, which can hardly be achieved in previous diffusion-based generative recommenders like DreamRec.

4.3. Recommendation Strategies under Various Linear Transformations

We are now capable of generating oracle item embeddings based on both interaction histories and intention instructions. However, as observed in previous work (Yang et al., 2023), the generated oracle items may fall outside the candidate set. Therefore, we need recommendation strategies that adapt to linear transformations which preserve variance within DDIM, while facilitating the recommendation of actual items more effectively, as explained in Section 4.1.3.

4.3.1. Intention-understanding Recommendation under Dot-product Preserving

When set as 𝒜⁢(𝐞)=a⁢𝐞,𝒜⁢(𝐞)=a⁢𝐞𝐎formulae-sequence𝒜𝐞𝑎𝐞𝒜𝐞𝑎𝐞𝐎\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=a\mathbf{e},\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=a\mathbf{e}\mathbf% {O}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = italic_a bold_e , caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = italic_a bold_eO (𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O}bold_O is defined in Equation (8)), the linear transformation 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A preserves the order of dot product, i.e., ⟨𝒜⁢(𝐱),𝒜⁢(𝐲)⟩≥⟨𝒜⁢(𝐱),𝒜⁢(𝐳)⟩𝒜𝐱𝒜𝐲𝒜𝐱𝒜𝐳\langle\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{x}),\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{y})\rangle\geq\langle% \mathcal{A}(\mathbf{x}),\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{z})\rangle⟨ caligraphic_A ( bold_x ) , caligraphic_A ( bold_y ) ⟩ ≥ ⟨ caligraphic_A ( bold_x ) , caligraphic_A ( bold_z ) ⟩ if ⟨𝐱,𝐲⟩≥⟨𝐱,𝐳⟩𝐱𝐲𝐱𝐳\langle\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\rangle\geq\langle\mathbf{x},\mathbf{z}\rangle⟨ bold_x , bold_y ⟩ ≥ ⟨ bold_x , bold_z ⟩ for any 𝐱,𝐲,𝐳𝐱𝐲𝐳\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z}bold_x , bold_y , bold_z. If transformation 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) preserves the order of the dot product, the diffusion model can learn the dot product structure during training, enabling it to generate oracle item embeddings guided by user textual intention. Consequently, by recommending items that have the highest dot-product value with oracle item embedding, iDreamRec could retrieve real items in the candidate set under the guidance of both interaction histories and textual intention, as discussed in Section 4.2.

In addition to preserving dot-product, transformation 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) also maintains the mean of the embeddings, either as 𝝁=a⁢Mean⁢(𝐄)𝝁𝑎Mean𝐄\bm{\mu}=a\text{Mean}(\mathbf{E})bold_italic_μ = italic_a Mean ( bold_E ) or 𝝁=a⁢Mean⁢(𝐄𝐎)𝝁𝑎Mean𝐄𝐎\bm{\mu}=a\text{Mean}(\mathbf{E}\mathbf{O})bold_italic_μ = italic_a Mean ( bold_EO ), implying the existence of distance between oracle item distribution q⁢(𝐞L|𝐞<L)𝑞conditionalsubscript𝐞𝐿subscript𝐞absent𝐿q(\mathbf{e}_{L}|\mathbf{e}_{<L})italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pure noise 𝒩⁢(𝟎,𝐈)𝒩0𝐈\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{I})caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , bold_I ). During the inference process, the generation of oracle items could be achieved by gradually recovering oracle item embedding from pure noise as Equation (6). Therefore, more inference steps are required to preserve the order of the dot product and bridge the distance between the oracle item distribution and pure noise.

4.3.2. Efficient Recommendation under Zero-mean Preserving

As analyzed above, we could set the linear transformation as 𝒜⁢(𝐞)=(𝐞−𝒖)⁢𝐎⁢𝚲−𝟏𝟐,(𝐞−𝒖)⁢𝐎⁢𝚲−12⁢𝐎𝒜𝐞𝐞𝒖𝐎superscript𝚲12𝐞𝒖𝐎superscript𝚲12𝐎\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\mathbf{\Lambda^{-\frac{1% }{2}}},(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\bm{\Lambda}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\mathbf{O}caligraphic_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O bold_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O bold_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O and (𝐞−𝒖)⁢𝐎⁢𝚲−12⁢𝐎T𝐞𝒖𝐎superscript𝚲12superscript𝐎𝑇(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\bm{\Lambda}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\mathbf{O}^{T}( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O bold_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (𝝁=Mean⁢(𝐄)𝝁Mean𝐄\bm{\mu}=\text{Mean}(\mathbf{E})bold_italic_μ = Mean ( bold_E ) and 𝐎,𝚲𝐎𝚲\mathbf{O},\bm{\Lambda}bold_O , bold_Λ are defined in Equation (8)). Under these transformations, we have: Mean⁢(𝒜⁢(𝐞Lt))=αt⁢Mean⁢(𝐞L0)=𝟎Mean𝒜superscriptsubscript𝐞𝐿𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡Meansuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝐿00\text{Mean}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e}_{L}^{t}))=\sqrt{\alpha_{t}}\text{Mean}(% \mathbf{e}_{L}^{0})=\mathbf{0}Mean ( caligraphic_A ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = square-root start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG Mean ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = bold_0 and Var⁢(𝒜⁢(𝐞Lt))=αt⁢Var⁢(𝐞L0)+(1−αt)⁢𝐈=𝐈Var𝒜superscriptsubscript𝐞𝐿𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡Varsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝐿01subscript𝛼𝑡𝐈𝐈\text{Var}(\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{e}_{L}^{t}))=\alpha_{t}\text{Var}(\mathbf{e}_{L% }^{0})+(1-\alpha_{t})\mathbf{I}=\mathbf{I}Var ( caligraphic_A ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Var ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( 1 - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_I = bold_I. This implies that all noisy data distributions 𝐞Ltsuperscriptsubscript𝐞𝐿𝑡\mathbf{e}_{L}^{t}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have zero mean and an identity covariance matrix for all t∈[0,T]𝑡0𝑇t\in[0,T]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , italic_T ], indicating there is no average distance between them. Under such circumstances, the inference process could be much more efficient in accuracy and time. Specifically, high recommendation accuracy can be achieved with a single-step generation, while multi-step generation further enhances it.

5. Experiments

In this section, we conducted extensive experiments to answer the following research questions:

  • •

    RQ1: Could iDreamRec bring performance improvement by incorporating consistent item distribution modeling with Text Embedding Models?

  • •

    RQ2: Could iDreamRec generate oracle items under the guidance of intention instructions?

  • •

    RQ3: What are the main factors that impact the performance of iDreamRec?

5.1. Experimental Setup

Datasets. We use four real-world datasets:

  • •

    Goodreads is collected from the Goodreads platform 222https://www.goodreads.com/. We utilize ChatGPT to generate missing genres and descriptions.

  • •

    MovieLens (Harper and Konstan, 2016) is a commonly used movie recommendation dataset that contains user ratings, movie titles, and genres. For MovieLens, we utilize ChatGPT to generate descriptions.

  • •

    Steam (Kang and McAuley, 2018) encompasses user reviews for video games on the Steam Store. For Steam, we utilize ChatGPT to generate descriptions.

  • •

    Amazon-TV (Hou et al., 2024) contains information and reviews for a wide range of movies on Amazon. Since the textual information is sufficiently rich, we do not prompt ChatGPT for any additional textual content.

In general, the four datasets represent different recommendation scenarios, while Amazon TV is more sparse, featuring over 40,000 items. The statistical information is shown in Table 3. We retain the 20-core datasets and filter out users and items with fewer than twenty interactions except MovieLens, which keeps the original dataset. Subsequently, we arrange all sequences chronologically and preserve the last 10 interactions as interaction history. For sequences with less than 10 interactions, we would pad them to 10 with a padding token. Then, we partition the data into training, validation, and testing sets at an 8:1:1 ratio. Regarding item text, we utilized GPT to enhance the textual information of the items, except for Amazon TV, which has sufficiently rich text information. Then, we concatenate the text information of items, including titles, genres, and descriptions, and input them into OpenAI’s TEM text-embeddings-3-small to obtain textual item embeddings. For statistics of datasets, please refer to Table 3.

Compared Methods. We compare the proposed approach with the following baseline methods:

  • •

    SASRec (Kang and McAuley, 2018) takes advantage of the self-attention mechanism in Transformer to capture users’ historical preference from interaction histories using learnable ID embedding.

  • •

    Caser (Tang and Wang, 2018) uses horizontal and vertical convolutional filters to capture sequential patterns at the point-level, union-level to allow skip behaviors using learnable ID embedding.

  • •

    MoRec (Yuan et al., 2023) employs item characteristics derived from text descriptions encoded with a text encoder, or other modal information with its corresponding modal encoder, and performs dimensional transformation to align with SASRec.

  • •

    UniSRec (Hou et al., 2022) proposes an architecture based on parametric whitening and a mixture-of-experts enhanced adaptor to transform original text embeddings to adapt SASRec.

  • •

    DiffRec (Wang et al., 2023b), on behalf of diffusion-based discriminative recommendation models, utilizes diffusion models to model the distribution of probability vectors for each item per user.

  • •

    DreamRec (Yang et al., 2023), a diffusion-based generative recommender, reshape sequential recommendation as oracle item generation.

Overall, we compared traditional discriminative recommenders using trainable ID embeddings represented by SASRec and Caser, recommenders based on text embeddings represented by MoRec and UniSRec, and diffusion-based generative recommenders represented by DiffRec and DreamRec.

To ensure a fairer comparison, the methods based on text embeddings all utilize the same text embeddings from OpenAI’s TEM text-embeddings-3-small as ours iDreamRec. After acquiring text embeddings by OpenAI’s TEM text-embeddings-3-small, iDreamRec utilize linear transformation 𝐀⁢(𝐞)=(𝐞−𝒖)⁢𝐎⁢𝚲−12⁢𝐎T𝐀𝐞𝐞𝒖𝐎superscript𝚲12superscript𝐎𝑇\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\bm{\Lambda}^{-\frac{1}{2}% }\mathbf{O}^{T}bold_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O bold_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_O start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or 𝐀⁢(𝐞)=(𝐞−𝒖)⁢𝐎⁢Λ−12𝐀𝐞𝐞𝒖𝐎superscriptΛ12\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{e})=(\mathbf{e}-\bm{u})\mathbf{O}\Lambda^{-\frac{1}{2}}bold_A ( bold_e ) = ( bold_e - bold_italic_u ) bold_O roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to preserve zero-mean and variance of identity matrix as section 4.3.2. Thereby, we could achieve one-step generative recommendation with high sampling quality. In our experiments, UniSRec and MoRec also get use of the same text embeddings instead of [CLS] embeddings from BERT.

Training Protocol. We implement all models with Python 3.7 and PyTorch 1.12.1 in Nvidia GeForce RTX 3090. We leverage AdamW as the optimizer. The embedding dimension of items is fixed as 1536 across all models. The learning rate is tuned in the range of {0.001,0.0001,0.00001,0.000001}0.0010.00010.000010.000001\left\{0.001,0.0001,0.00001,0.000001\right\}{ 0.001 , 0.0001 , 0.00001 , 0.000001 }. For SASRec, Caser, MoRec, and UniSRec, we use binary cross-entropy loss and perform negative sampling randomly at the ratio of {16,32,64}163264\left\{16,32,64\right\}{ 16 , 32 , 64 }, while there is no negative sampling in DiffRec, DreamRec, and our iDreamRec. For both DreamRec and our iDreamRec, we fix the unconditional training probability p𝑝pitalic_p as 0.1 suggested by (Ho and Salimans, 2022) and set the total diffusion step T𝑇Titalic_T fixed as 2000, and the personalized guidance strength w𝑤witalic_w in the range of {0,2,4,6,8,10}0246810\left\{0,2,4,6,8,10\right\}{ 0 , 2 , 4 , 6 , 8 , 10 } as DreamRec. As for inference, DreamRec conducts T𝑇Titalic_T-step generation while our iDreamRec achieves one-step generation.

Evaluation Protocol. We adopt two widely-used metrics to evaluate the performance of recommendation (Kang and McAuley, 2018; Yang et al., 2023): hit ratio (HR@⁢K@𝐾@K@ italic_K) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG@⁢K@𝐾@K@ italic_K), where K𝐾Kitalic_K is set to 5 and 10. And we calculate them based on the rankings of all items other than some sampled items. The full ranking strategy to some extent provides a fairer assessment (Krichene and Rendle, 2020).

5.2. Main Results (RQ1)

In this section, we compare iDreamRec with the baselines in terms of recommendation performance and analyze the reasons behind the results. The main experiment results are shown in Table 1.

In general, iDreamRec substantially outperforms compared approaches, highlighting the effectiveness of consistent item embedding modeling for diffusion-based generative recommenders, which is achieved by prompting ChatGPT and integrating pretrained Text Embedding Models in iDreamRec. Moreover, we can observe that DreamRec achieves pleasing performance on MovieLens and Goodreads data, while its performance on Steam and Amazon-TV is unsatisfactory. This performance gap can be attributed to that the inconsistency of randomly initialized ID embeddings would be amplified with the growth in the number of items, with much more items in Steam and Amazon-TV data than MovieLens and Goodreads. In contrast, iDreamRec models a more consistent embedding distribution of items, thus maintaining the best performance with a larger number of items.

5.3. Results with Intention Instructions (RQ2)

In this section, we progress to further demonstrate the intention instruction following the capability of iDreamRec, where a practical challenge lies in the lack of intention information in public recommendation datasets. To resolve this challenge, we compromise to prompt ChatGPT to generate the user intention 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y by providing a textual description of the item of interest to the user. Afterward, we examine whether iDreamRec could follow intention instruction 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y and provide higher recommendation accuracy towards the target item as discussed in Section 4.2. The results are shown in Figure LABEL:figIntention.

From Figure LABEL:figIntention we can observe that by varying the guidance strength of intention instructions, iDreamRec shows sensitiveness towards the prediction accuracy on target items, and could outperform historical interaction guidance under certain guidance strengths. Note that the intention instruction is not involved in the training of iDreamRec, and only integrated in the generation phase as described in Section 4.2, which implies the flexibility and stability of integrating more text-based guidance in iDreamRec.

5.4. Ablation Studys (RQ3)

To answer RQ3, we conducted ablation experiments to deeply analyze the contribution of key considerations in iDreamRec.

Firstly, we conduct an ablation experiment to analyze the impact of different types of embeddings on iDreamRec. The results are shown in Figure 4. To sum up, the consistency of item embeddings is a crucial adjective of the performance of iDreamRec, even diffusion-based generative recommenders. And rich item textual information will also be beneficial to the performance of iDreamRec with text embeddings. Moreover, even when using pre-trained ID embeddings, iDreamRec still demonstrates good performance, indicating that other types of consistent item embeddings are also applicable to iDreamRec.

Secondly, we conduct a study on the impact of recommender frameworks on text embeddings, with the results presented in Figure reffigText. The results demonstrate that diffusion-based recommenders can leverage consistent text embeddings from TEM more effectively than traditional recommenders.

5.5. Time Efficiency

The high inference time, a well-known drawback of diffusion models, renders diffusion-based recommenders impractical. Therefore, we will analyze the inference time efficiency of iDreamRec in this section. The results are shown in Figure 6. As shown in the figure, iDreamRec significantly improves inference efficiency compared to other diffusion-based recommendation systems, and it is even comparable to traditional recommenders.

6. Conclusion

We propose iDreamRec, which models consistent, context-aware embeddings encoded by advanced Text Embedding Models (TEM) and incorporates intention instructions for guiding the generation of the oracle item. Specifically, iDreamRec substantially encapsulates prior knowledge encoded in LLMs and TEMs into fixed item embeddings, thus nudging diffusion models to capture a more consistent oracle item distribution than ID embeddings. More importantly, the item embedding space of iDreamRec lies in accordance with the output space of TEM, allowing for the use of more informative intention instructions for oracle item generation. Experiments demonstrate that iDreamRec consistently enhances diffusion-based generative recommenders and enables the integration of intention instructions for more precise and effective recommendation results.

7. Limitation

There are also a few limitations of iDreamRec:

  • •

    underexplored intention instructions: The intention instructions in iDreamRec are either heuristically constructed or generated by GPT, which differ from actual user inputs. It arises from the lack of real-world intention instruction data. Additionally, the effectiveness of intention guidance based on Text Embedding Models (TEM) is worth exploring. Our experiments revealed that, apart from the semantic of intentions, the syntactic structure might also has an impact as shown in Figure 3.

  • •

    high latent dimension: The latent dimension of iDreamRec is determined by the output dimension of TEM, which is often significantly larger than the hidden dimension of traditional recommendation systems, typically set at 64.
